posts.title: Educational Codeforces Round 81 (Rated for Div. 2) B. Infinite Prefixes
posts.text: B. Infinite PrefixesYou are given string s of length n consisting of 0-s and 1-s. You build an infinite string t as a concatenation of an infinite number of strings s, or t = ssssâ€¦ For example, if s = 10010, then t= 100101001010010... Calculate the number of prefixes of t with balance equal to x. The balance of some string q is equal to cnt0,q âˆ’ cnt1,q, where cnt0,q is the number of occurrences of 0 in q, and cnt1,q is the number of occurrences of 1 in q. The number of such prefixes can be infinite; if it is so, you must say that. A prefix is a string consisting of several first letters of a given string, without any reorders. An empty prefix is also a valid prefix. For example, the string â€œabcdâ€œ has 5 prefixes: empty string, â€œaâ€œ, â€œabâ€œ, â€œabcâ€œ and â€œabcdâ€œ. InputThe first line contains the single integer T (1 â‰¤ T â‰¤ 100)â€” the number of test cases. Next 2T lines contain descriptions of test cases â€” two lines per test case. The first line contains two integers n and x (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 105, âˆ’109 â‰¤ x â‰¤ 109) â€” the length of string s and the desired balance, respectively. The second line contains the binary string s (|s| = n, si âˆˆ {0,1}). Itâ€™s guaranteed that the total sum of n doesnâ€™t exceed 105. OutputPrint T integers â€” one per test case. For each test case print the number of prefixes or âˆ’1 if there is an infinite number of such prefixes. Exampleinput4 6 10 010010 5 3 10101 1 0 0 2 0 01output3 0 1 -1NoteIn the first test case, there are 3 good prefixes of t: with length 28, 30 and 32. } } if(x==0) ans++; if(flag) cout<<-1<<endl; else cout<<ans<<endl; } return 0; } è¡¥é¢˜è¿‡ç¨‹ä¸­æˆ‘è¾“å‡º -1 ç”¨äº† puts,å¯¼è‡´äº†ä¸æ–­åœ° Wrong answer on test 4 ï¼Œç™¾åº¦åæ‰çŸ¥é“ å…³é—­åŒæ­¥æµ (std::ios::sync_with_stdio(false) )ä¹‹å,ä¸èƒ½å†ä½¿ç”¨ scanf ã€printfã€getsã€puts â€¦ã€‚æ˜¨å¤©æœ‰ä¸€é“é¢˜æ¢è¡Œç”¨äº†endlä¹Ÿå¯¼è‡´äº†waï¼Œæ”¹ç”¨ â€˜\nâ€™ å°± ac,éš¾å—äº†æˆ‘å¥½é•¿æ—¶é—´ã€‚æˆ‘å†³å®šä»¥åæ…¢æ…¢åœ°æ”¾å¼ƒcinã€coutã€‚ è™½ç„¶å®ƒå¾ˆé¦™ã€‚

posts.title: Codeforces Round #608 (Div. 2) B. Blocks
posts.text: B. BlocksThere are n blocks arranged in a row and numbered from left to right, starting from one. Each block is either black or white. You may perform the following operation zero or more times: choose two adjacent blocks and invert their colors (white block becomes black, and vice versa). You want to find a sequence of operations, such that they make all the blocks having the same color. You donâ€™t have to minimize the number of operations, but it should not exceed 3 â‹… n. If it is impossible to find such a sequence of operations, you need to report it. InputThe first line contains one integer n (2 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 200) â€” the number of blocks. The second line contains one string s consisting of n characters, each character is either â€œWâ€ or â€œBâ€. If the i-th character is â€œWâ€, then the i-th block is white. If the i-th character is â€œBâ€, then the i-th block is black. OutputIf it is impossible to make all the blocks having the same color, print âˆ’1. Otherwise, print an integer k (0 â‰¤ k â‰¤ 3â‹…n) â€” the number of operations. Then print k integers p1,p2,â€¦,pk (1â‰¤pjâ‰¤nâˆ’1), where pj is the position of the left block in the pair of blocks that should be affected by the j-th operation. If there are multiple answers, print any of them. Examplesinput 8 BWWWWWWBoutput 3 6 2 4input 4 BWBBoutput -1input 5 WWWWWoutput 0input 3 BWBoutput 2 2 1 NoteIn the first example, it is possible to make all blocks black in 3 operations. Start with changing blocks 6 and 7, so the sequence is â€œBWWWWBBBâ€œ. Then change blocks 2 and 3, so the sequence is â€œBBBWWBBâ€œ. And finally, change blocks 4 and 5, so all blocks are black. It is impossible to make all colors equal in the second example. All blocks are already white in the third example. In the fourth example it is possible to make all blocks white in two operations: first operation is to change blocks 2 and 3 (so the sequence is â€œBBWâ€œ), and then change blocks 1 and 2 (so all blocks are white). posts.text: #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; // T:ç¡®å®šå±äºæœ€å°ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹é›†åˆ // S:å‰©ä½™èŠ‚ç‚¹é›†åˆ int a[3010][3010]; int d[3010];// d[x], xè¡¨ç¤ºxåŠ å…¥Tæ—¶é€‰å‡ºçš„æœ€å°è¾¹çš„æƒå€¼ bool vis[3010];// vis[x]==trueè¡¨ç¤ºè¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹å·²ç»åŠ å…¥äº†Té›†åˆ int n,m,ans=0; void prim() { memset(d,0x3f,sizeof(d)); memset(vis,0,sizeof(vis)); d[1]=0; for(int i=1; i<n; i++)//å¾ªç¯n-1æ¬¡ æ¯æ¬¡æ‰¾å‡ºä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹åŠ å…¥T { int x=0; for(int j=1; j<=n; j++)//éå†æ‰€æœ‰èŠ‚ç‚¹ { //å½“å‰d[]æ•°ç»„å­˜å‚¨çš„æ˜¯å„ä¸ªèŠ‚ç‚¹è·ç¦»ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘çš„æœ€å°æƒå€¼ if(!vis[j] && (x==0 || d[j]<d[x])) //!vis[j]è¡¨ç¤ºè¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹å°šæœªåŠ å…¥Té›†åˆ x=j; //é€‰å‡ºè·ç¦»ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘æœ€è¿‘çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹ } vis[x]=1;//å°†è¯¥èŠ‚ç‚¹åŠ å…¥åˆ°ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘ä¸­(Té›†åˆ) for(int y=1; y<=n; y++) { if(!vis[y])//æ–°åŠ äº†ä¸€ä¸ªç‚¹ï¼Œå°±ç»´æŠ¤è¯¥ç‚¹åˆ°è¿˜æ²¡æœ‰åŠ å…¥Té›†åˆçš„ç‚¹çš„è·ç¦» d[y]=min(d[y],a[x][y]);//å–è·ç¦»ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘ } } } int main() { cin>>n>>m; //æ„å»ºé‚»æ¥çŸ©é˜µ memset(a,0x3f,sizeof(a)); for(int i=1; i<=n; i++) a[i][i]=0; for(int i=1; i<=m; i++) { int x,y,z; cin>>x>>y>>z; a[x][y]=a[y][x]=min(a[x][y],z); } //æ±‚æœ€å°ç”Ÿæˆæ ‘ prim(); for(int i=2; i<=n; i++) ans+=d[i]; cout<<ans<<endl; return 0; } /* è¾“å…¥ è¾“å‡º15 6 10 1 2 6 1 3 1 1 4 5 2 3 5 2 5 3 3 4 5 3 5 6 3 6 4 4 6 2 5 6 6 */

posts.excerpt: æ™®é€šç‰ˆ int a[3010][3010],d[3010]; int n,m; bool v[3010]; void dijkstra() { memset(d,INF,sizeof(d)); memset(v,0,sizeof(v)); d[1]=0; for(int i=1; i<n; i++) { int x=0; for(int j=1; j<=n; j++) { if(!v[j] && (x==0 || d[j]<d[x])) x=j; } v[x]=1; for(int y=1; y<=n; y++) if(!v[y]) d[y]=min(d[y],d[x]+a[x][y]); } }
posts.text: æ™®é€šç‰ˆ int a[3010][3010],d[3010]; int n,m; bool v[3010]; void dijkstra() { memset(d,INF,sizeof(d)); memset(v,0,sizeof(v)); d[1]=0; for(int i=1; i<n; i++) { int x=0; for(int j=1; j<=n; j++) { if(!v[j] && (x==0 || d[j]<d[x])) x=j; } v[x]=1; for(int y=1; y<=n; y++) if(!v[y]) d[y]=min(d[y],d[x]+a[x][y]); } } å †ä¼˜åŒ–ç‰ˆ #include<bits/stdc++.h> using namespace std; typedef long long ll; const int N = 1000010; const int INF = 0x3f3f3f3f; int n,m; struct edge { int to; int r; } ; typedef pair<int,int> P; vector<edge> a[N]; int d[50005]; void dijkstra(int s) { priority_queue<P,vector<P>,greater<P> >que; memset(d,INF,sizeof(d)); d[s]=0; que.push(P(0,s)); while(que.size()) { P p=que.top(); que.pop(); int v=p.second; if(d[v]<p.first) continue; for(int i=0; i<a[v].size(); i++) { edge e=a[v][i]; if(d[e.to]>d[v]+e.r) { d[e.to]=d[v]+e.r; que.push(P(d[e.to],e.to)); } } } } int main() { cin>>n>>m; int x,y,r; while(m--) { cin>>x>>y>>r; edge t1,t2; t1.to=y; t1.r=r; t2.to=x; t2.r=r; a[x].push_back(t1); a[y].push_back(t2); } dijkstra(1); for(int i=0; i<=n; i++) cout<<d[i]<<" "; cout<<endl; return 0; }
